principles.label: Public Safety Paramount
principles.definition: Engineers shall hold paramount the safety, health, and welfare of the public in the performance of their professional duties
principles.manifestation_in_case: Omitted safety features in AI-generated designs could compromise public welfare
principles.source_text: conflicting with the Fundamental Canon I.1, hold paramount the safety, health, and welfare of the public

principles.label: Technology as Tool Principle
principles.definition: Technology must be used as an aid to engineering practice, not as a substitute for professional judgment
principles.manifestation_in_case: AI tools should augment but not replace engineering judgment
principles.source_text: technology must not replace or be used as a substitute for engineering judgement

principles.label: Responsible Charge Principle
principles.definition: Engineers must be actively engaged in the engineering process from conception to completion
principles.manifestation_in_case: Engineer A's cursory review of AI designs may not satisfy responsible charge requirements
principles.source_text: Being actively engaged in the engineering process, from conception to completion

principles.label: Attribution Principle
principles.definition: Engineers shall give credit for engineering work to those to whom credit is due
principles.manifestation_in_case: Question of whether AI contributions require attribution
principles.source_text: engineers shall give credit for engineering work to those to whom credit is due

principles.label: Avoidance of Deception Principle
principles.definition: Engineers shall avoid deceptive acts in solicitation of employment or professional engagement
principles.manifestation_in_case: Non-disclosure of AI use evaluated against deception standards
principles.source_text: Fundamental Canon I.5 requires an Engineer to avoid deceptive acts, which was not violated here
